title: Sasha Klein’s Portfolio
text:
1 Welcome!
Hello there! I’m Sasha, a current Master’s student of Environment & Sustainability Management at Georgetown University, McDonough School of Business. Since beginning this program, I discovered an unexpected passion for data modeling and visualizations.
My strength lies in simplifying complex data into understandable visuals—a skill I’m continually refining through a dedication to learning and adopting the latest methods.
My data analysis journey is propelled by a mission to merge data modeling with environmental sustainability. I aim to develop data-driven solutions addressing significant environmental challenges, intending to communicate these insights effectively to prompt policy and behavioral changes towards sustainability.
Moreover, my focus includes extensive research into the impacts of climate change, exploring mitigation strategies through data modeling and visualization. My goal is to render scientific information accessible to diverse audiences, empowering action across communities and stakeholders.
Hailing from the US Virgin Islands, firsthand experiences with the effects of anthropogenic climate change fuel my unwavering commitment to making a genuine impact. Beyond my professional work, you can find me reading at coffee shops, running, spending time with my dog, and cooking.

title: Elephant Browsing and Plant Mortality
text: The project aimed to explore and visualize environmental data related to biomass loss attributed to elephants and other disturbances in plant populations. It involves various tasks like creating new columns, filtering and visualizing data through histograms, scatterplots, bar plots, and predictive modeling. The goal is to understand relationships between elephant density, age categories, biomass loss, and probabilities of significant biomass loss due to disturbances, providing insights into ecological impacts.

title: Elephant Browsing and Plant Mortality
text: The project aimed to explore and visualize environmental data related to biomass loss attributed to elephants and other disturbances in plant populations. It involves various tasks like creating new columns, filtering and visualizing data through histograms, scatterplots, bar plots, and predictive modeling. The goal is to understand relationships between elephant density, age categories, biomass loss, and probabilities of significant biomass loss due to disturbances, providing insights into ecological impacts.

title: Elephant Browsing and Plant Mortality
text:
0.2 Methods
The project takes original environmental data collected in the field and transforms that data into usable forms and outputs for conservation and sustainability. This project follows the workflow that is used to craft analyses that can be published in reports or peer-reviewed publications. Further, it focuses on visualizing data from a study on elephant browsing and plant mortality in semi- arid regions of Namibia (Kindermann et al., 2022)

title: Elephant Browsing and Plant Mortality
text:
0.3 Outputs



The visualization presents a boxplot showing the distribution of response percentages across different Elephant Density levels, complemented by overlaid jitter points denoting the mean percent proportion loss due to any disturbance across these densities categorized by age. The boxplot offers insight into response variability, while the jittered points highlight the average proportion loss, providing a comparative view based on Elephant Density and Age Category. The plot aims to reveal potential correlations between Elephant Density, response variation, and disturbance-induced losses among different age groups.





The Sankey diagram visualizes the flow of biomass proportions across different vegetation types, ages of vegetation, elephant densities, and types of disturbances. It illustrates how biomass distribution changes among savanna and woodland, various age categories, elephant densities, and the relative impact of disturbances like elephants, fire, woodcutting, browsers, abiotic factors, and other unidentified influences on the ecosystem’s biomass loss. The diagram’s nodes and flows showcase the proportional distribution and shifts of biomass among these categories, providing an overview of their interrelationships and impacts within the ecosystem.

title: Impacts of Climate Disturbances on Coral Reefs
text: Our aim is to understand the global influence of different climate disturbances on coral coverage around the world.  To craft our visualization, we’re drawing from a comprehensive study that compiled research findings on coral cover loss worldwide (Cresswell et al., 2023). Our goal is to capture and illustrate the intricate relationship between climate-induced changes and their impact on coral ecosystems across diverse regions.

title: Impacts of Climate Disturbances on Coral Reefs
text: Our aim is to understand the global influence of different climate disturbances on coral coverage around the world.  To craft our visualization, we’re drawing from a comprehensive study that compiled research findings on coral cover loss worldwide (Cresswell et al., 2023). Our goal is to capture and illustrate the intricate relationship between climate-induced changes and their impact on coral ecosystems across diverse regions.

title: Impacts of Climate Disturbances on Coral Reefs
text:
0.2 Methods
We produced our visualizations based on a data set about global coral cover before and after certain disturbances such as storms and cyclones, temperature stress and coastal run-off from flooding. We worked on a linear regression and arrived at a final model where the response variable, Impact, depended upon the longitude interacting with disturbance type, the disturbance year and the mean of the coral coverage before the disturbance

title: Impacts of Climate Disturbances on Coral Reefs
text:
0.3 Outputs





The visualization illustrates global impacts on corals categorized by different disturbance types using a bubble map overlaying coral sites across longitude and latitude coordinates. Each bubble’s size and color denote the magnitude and variation of disturbances across geographical locations and types.
